9th grade geometry came in handy here (Oh yeah and physics class)

I'll try to break down the Coefficient of Restitution (CoR) for those who are less familiar with the math language & abbreviations in case anyone is confused. The CoR Is given by dividing the final velocity of the second object (vb) minus the final velocity of the first object (va) by the initial velocity of the first object (ua) minus the initial velocity of the second (ub). So the formula looks like this —› (vb - va / ua - ub). So Final velocity of the wood block (7.12meters/second) minus the final velocity of the steel ball (.36m/s) divided by the initial velocity of the steel ball (33m/s) minus the initial velocity of the wood block (0m/s). Therefore CoR= (7.12m/s - .36m/s)/(33m/s - 0m/s) = (6.76m/s)/(33m/s) = .204848..... Due to the numbers we used for our calculations (e.g. the .36m/s), we are limited to only 2 significant figures. So we are left with .20 as our CoR. We no longer have m/s because they cancel out in the division.

Coefficient of restitution is:

(vb2-va2)/(va1-vb1)

va1 is 33 m/s
vb1 is 0 m/s
va2 is .36 m/s
vb2 is 7.12 m/s

(7.12 - .36)/(33) = .204848

@AndrewPseudonym 
Sure.  Velocity equals distance travelled divided by the time it took to travel it.  I measured the length of a brick and came up with a pixels/inch ratio.  Then I selected a position that the head of the hammer was at, clicked forward several times and multiplied the frames by the interval between the frame to obtain the time.  Divide and you're done!
